name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @JasonCBurbank Take a look at 'Step 4: Plastic Recycling' in the following update to answer your question (and more!): https://t.co/Ql54aeJACK

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @avcarol87 Thank you for your wise and kind words. It fills us with so much gratitude to have incredible supporters, such as yourself on this journey with us!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Sietse_Bolt Interesting question - while we have some ideas, we have not yet tested this. As we move forward in this process we will be conducting additional tests to learn more about the plastic. Read more here: https://t.co/Ql54aeJACK

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @BjornAke72 We are not planning on establishing our own recycling facilities, but will be working with partners to ensure our recycling capabilities can scale as our catch increases.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @BarneyOram The plastic does not have to be a certain quality, but has to have certain properties and be sorted into polymer type prior to recycling. You can read more about the process here: https://t.co/Ql54aeJACK

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @andrea_dipiazza This plastic was not for sale - as it will be transformed into the first product made from verified ocean plastic.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @sjanus_pl Interesting question! Our current focus is on developing cleanup technology, and transforming this trash to treasure. We'll be collaborating with selected partners for our recycling needs.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @ohnomukherjee We will be using the granules to produce our own products, made of certified plastic from the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. Learn more here: https://t.co/Ql54aeJACK

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @KarenvanEtten2 @BoyanSlat Welcome aboard, Karen! We're so glad to have you joining us on our plastic journey!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @vaanhold We'll be using the plastic to make our own durable, sustainable products. Here is more information on the process: https://t.co/Ql54aeJACK

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @yvopr Pavements eventually wear down, which generates microscopic dust. This dust then takes plastic back into the environment. Our goal is to turn the collected ocean plastic into durable and recyclable products - read more here: https://t.co/Ql54aeJACK

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @ticofab Thank you for your support! We receive many requests for visits, so we must be careful in honoring these in order to stay focused on our core mission. Unfortunately, this means that it's not usually possible for the general public to visit our offices.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Nasehv Hi Richard - if you'd like to share you idea, please send an email to info@theoceancleanup.com

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @fredsteenbergen The plastic granules are not the end goal. We will be using them ourselves for our own product as part of the plastic journey. Find out more here: https://t.co/Mot4tVav41

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @chaosprism Indeed Stuart. However we intend to make beautiful and sustainable products out of the granulate. This way we can reinvest 100% of the proceeds into our cleanup efforts, and achieve our common goal of plastic free oceans!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @cocopip There are many ways to help like spreading our mission, reducing your plastic waste and recycling where possible. For a more complete list, please send us a direct message!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @nicoleamurray The products that we are aiming to make out of this very special material, will be products that people cherish and therefore won't throw back into the ocean. To learn more, take a look at one of our previous press announcements: https://t.co/wqdTu5MwD5

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Another important moment in the Plastic Journey: we have successfully finalized the recycling step. This is the first time that plastic from the Great Pacific Garbage Patch has been recycled into plastic granulate. https://t.co/IYl85daoCq

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Countcyber Thanks, Dennis! Our observations so far have shown that fish simply swim around the device, and birds consider it a landing point! To date we have seen no negative interactions between the Interceptor and passing animals.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @AhPeroMira @pedalafondonet Due to Covid-19, the deployment of Interceptor 004 was delayed. As soon as it is safe to return, we shall complete deployment and it will begin cleaning!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text:
With ten steps in total, the Plastic Journey spans from the moment we captured the plastic in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch to the day we start our next cleanup operation.

We created an overview to show you what goes into each step, check it out here: https://t.co/O3zQ6RIZJL

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @AtelierEnglish Interceptor 004 is the same size as Interceptors 002 through 006. Interceptor 001 was our first prototype, and looks a bit different than the other three. You can read about the changes from Interceptor 001 to 002 here: https://t.co/QxuAvkItPi

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @jamesrtyrrell Feedback is always welcome! If we want to tackle these 1000 rivers, we need to take our learnings to make the design smarter and more preparted for series production.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @jamesrtyrrell The first series of Interceptors were part of our pilot stage, allowing us to test our machine and note any areas that could be improved. Once we begin with a full scale roll-out, we expect the manufacturing and the deployment to go much quicker.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: You can now watch the first part of the Interceptor 004 series to learn how we built the machine that will be cleaning in Rio Ozama in the Dominican Republic: https://t.co/7AxpZzaLMb

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @johandyj The Interceptor is part of many initiatives necessary - including education - to combat plastic pollution. We focus on what we do best, developing technology, but we also initiate local partnerships for deployment, and will always include the aim of ensuring education as well.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text:
Interceptor 004: soon to be deployed in the Dominican Republic.

We have recorded the story of this system - from its construction, to baptism, and transfer to the Dominican Republic. It will become available in a series, to watch from June 25. https://t.co/szn9GuMZSj

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @P_lLarange Next is the scale up. We are currently in the design phase of System 002, which will launch in 2021.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @NoisenseMusicPr System 001/B returned to shore in November 2019, and we are currently incorporating the learnings from this mission into the design of  System 002 You can read more about it here: https://t.co/lTHnmv9eMV

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Here are a few moments from today one year ago. It was an important day for The Ocean Cleanup - on June 18, 2019, we launched our ocean cleanup System 001/B that would later bring in our first plastic catch. https://t.co/jix3pN2EZU

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @brutnaturefr @BoyanSlat @changeNOWsummit Thanks so much for sharing! To learn more about our mission to rid the world's oceans of plastic visit: https://t.co/wFLn7Osqq7

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @guitargil1 @Space4Europe The link does indeed take you to a registration page on LinkedIn. https://t.co/aTO4gPflBH

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: In the upcoming Plastic-Less Society webinar, Robin, Geospatial Analyst at The Ocean Cleanup, will be talking about our collaboration with @Space4Europe and how they’re helping us to detect plastic from space. Register below to join the event. https://t.co/F4XV7kWN62

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: RT @BoyanSlat: With lockdown eased, preps to deploy Interceptor 004 in the Dominican Republic have started up again! If all goes well, it s…
retweet_text: With lockdown eased, preps to deploy Interceptor 004 in the Dominican Republic have started up again! If all goes well, it should be fully installed next month https://t.co/joUNhoegUa

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @tommygun75214 System 001/B was brought back to port in November of 2019. We are currently hard at work taking our learnings from that mission and incorporating them into System 002. You can read more about it here: https://t.co/lTHnmv9eMV

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @BrattlandDiane We're glad that we can provide a little bit of brightness to your world, Diane. Thanks for your support!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: You can read our recap of 2019 in the newly published annual report: https://t.co/gDLXSdJCM8

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Thank you - every one of you. In 2019, over 80% of our funding came from individuals like you who supported us via our website or Facebook fundraisers. This allowed us to get our first plastic out of the ocean and deploy the first Interceptors. Your support makes a difference. https://t.co/Fa87BZZr2h

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Kathlee28059844 @BoyanSlat Thanks for reaching out! Please send us an e-mail to info@theoceancleanup.com and we will do our best to answer your questions!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @bhaveshshah @ravindrapusam1 @Benioff @UCSBenioffOcean Our goal is to tackle these 1000 most polluting rivers all over the world, in five years from rollout.  Whether each river will have an Interceptor depends on a variety of factors, but we hope to deploy wherever beneficial.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Milan23N We hope to be able to do so once we are able to resume travel and Interceptor deployments - stay tuned!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @mrssarahlouward @oceana @OurOcean @WorldOceansDay @CWN_ORG @oceanexplorer @GreenpeaceUK @SeaLifeTrust Go Noah! It's inspiring to see so many young people getting involved in helping to save our oceans!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @BrianLR19728 @SimonTurkas Good question! We by no means view any organisms as expendable. By minimization, we are referring to mitigation measures that are or could be implemented to reduce possible impact from our activities as we continue to learn.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @climatestate Thanks for flagging! We prefer the use of raw footage here: https://t.co/UGlJ4m3Wqs, and avoid re-uploads from our YouTube. For all material we ask it to be properly credited. We work with @team5pm to help us keep track of this. If you have any questions about this send us a DM.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Benioff @UCSBenioffOcean Thanks for sharing - we are looking forward to start cleaning in Kingston Harbour and get one step closer to our mission to rid the world's oceans of plastic!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @ravindrapusam1 @Benioff @BoyanSlat @UCSBenioffOcean Our aim is to tackle the 1000 highest polluting rivers world-wide, with the aid of the Interceptor. If you take a look at our interactive river sources map (https://t.co/HQvTQjIxiE), you'll find that the river Ganga is on our radar - stay tuned!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @mejoff @Benioff @UCSBenioffOcean Thank you so much for your support. Achieving our common goal of plastic free oceans would not be possible without the support from individuals, such as yourself.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @CommonZense101 We recognize that the GPGP is not going anywhere, and while we have had unscheduled learning opportunities, we remain a non-profit committed to ridding the world's oceans of plastic. We're hard at work on System 002, and are hopeful that the potential can become reality!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @crcdistribution We're glad to hear we helped to inspire your company to reduce plastic use. Well done!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @BrianLR19728 @SimonTurkas Ensuring we do not harm marine life is a top priority. We conducted an Environmental Impact Assessment for Mission One.  Once the next generation design is confirmed and before scale-up, we will conduct a new EIA. Read more here: https://t.co/NXiKwdbMlT

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @SimonEnion We are still committed to our goal of clean oceans - we will never stop!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @LondonBusman63 Every effort to keep plastic out of the oceans and rivers helps!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @j4ckl3 Our focus is on cleaning the legacy plastic in the oceans. That's a big enough job in itself! We hope that our efforts will inspire other initiatives to tackle the legislation,  prevention and education aspects of plastic pollution.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @opsealog Thank you so much for your support - we really appreciate it!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @LovesGlasto For our time, for our children's time, for their children's time - we hope to make lasting difference!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @GoLiveOutdoors Absolutely! Working together is key, and every effort makes a difference!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: What led you to support our mission towards clean oceans? Are you a surfer, a sailor, or someone who simply appreciates the ocean’s magnificence?

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text:
The ocean is what drives our mission and it's what brings us together as a team.

Happy #WorldOceansDay from all of us at The Ocean Cleanup. https://t.co/SMdaSowlw2

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @elifalper By removing floating legacy plastic before it degrades, we will help to eliminate future microplastic pollution. As our mission is a large one, we currently do not have the resources to tackle another issue. We hope other initiatives will be inspired to  take on this task.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @PDHMUSIC1 While we do have some ideas, for us working with ocean plastic is a new process. The first step we need to take is to understand the quality and characteristics of the plastic. Once this is done we will be able to determine what can be made. Be sure to stay tuned!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @SelenSwn Thank you so much for your kind words Selene. Knowing that we have incredible supporters such as yourself on this journey with us, also inspires and motivates us even more to achieve our shared goal of plastic free oceans!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @too_sham @CopernicusEU @sentinel_hub You are welcome to send your questions to info@theoceancleanup.com. They will then be forwarded to the appropriate department.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @FlorianTpt Interceptor 003 is awaiting final paperwork in Vietnam, and the deployment process for Interceptor 004 will resume when it is safe to return to the Dominican Republic. We'll be sure to keep our community updated as things progress!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @DamPedersen The last thing we would want is to lose a loyal supporter! We've sent you a DM and would be more than happy to help clear up any concerns.

text: @Craighasmillie We have several locations in Egypt targeted for our help in fighting plastic pollution, including the Nile. You can see the locations here: https://t.co/vwMHpQYqVH

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @too_sham @CopernicusEU @sentinel_hub Thanks for bringing this to our attention! We've passed it along to our research team!

text: @Icarustumbling That is indeed horrible. We have several locations in Egypt targeted for our help in tackling plastic pollution. You can find them on our map, here: https://t.co/vwMHpQYqVH

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @JrgenHemme1 In order to reach as many people as possible, our content is only in English. While we would love to make our content available in every language, as a small team with a huge mission, we simply do not have the time and resources to do so.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @BurriJoD Thank you so much for your continuous support - we are so appreciative!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Last week, we released an update where Lonneke and Eline of The Ocean Cleanup catch us up on the progress in our mission to rid the world's oceans of plastic and share some memorable moments at The Ocean Cleanup. Watch the conversation here: https://t.co/fGiGm3W00h

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @AtelierEnglish Hi Carrie - we're sorry to hear you're having trouble with your account. Can you please send an email to info@theoceancleanup.com and we'll be happy to help solve this problem!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @KalkmanMarnix We don't have a weight we can give you, but we can tell you that while the main purpose of Mission One (System 001 and 001/B) was for testing purposes, we managed to collect 60 1m3 bags of plastic as part of the by-catch.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @shellyrapp64 We have some ideas, but we first need to understand the characteristics of the ocean plastic we've collected before making a final determination.  You can join us on the journey from pollution to product here: https://t.co/ztrbyp4Cz6

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: You can sign up to get first access to the product made of plastic from the ocean- by doing so, you are helping to close the loop of this plastic’s journey and fund the cleanup of the next: https://t.co/ztrbypmdXG. (7/7)

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Mass balance is simply the dry weight of the plastic from when it was captured in the ocean, to the end of the recycling process when it is transformed into a product. This overall weight should remain constant throughout the process. (6/7)

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Traceability-  location, integrity, mass, and usage of the plastic is made traceable through detailed documentation. This evidence is maintained from when it is caught at sea to the finished product, which will come with GPS coordinates of where it was caught in the GPGP. (5/7) https://t.co/YZ8ji5oXNR

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Material integrity - the material gathered from the Great Pacific Garbage Patch (GPGP) is not mixed with material from other sources. Numbered seals and tags on storage containers ensure that the material can be traced through audits to demonstrate this. (4/7) https://t.co/ulqIoSF7N4

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: To solve this, we connected with @DNVGL (a global verification body), who agreed to establish a standard to verify the ocean plastic origin and bring transparency to the market. To be certified as ocean plastic, three main components must be confirmed: (3/7) https://t.co/m4EZE8skVF

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Problem: the market is saturated with “ocean plastic" products, where the unclear definition of what this entails leads to little traceability and ocean plastic products that have little to do with plastic taken out of the ocean. (2/7)

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: When creating a beautiful, sustainable product from the plastic caught in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, we want our supporters to be able to trust that the product they receive is really made of plastic from the ocean. (1/7) https://t.co/4V4NxEcama

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: To increase transparency of our plastic journey, we connected with global verification body @DNVGL and found a way to give supporters confidence that our products are truly made of plastic from the ocean through this independent, third party. Here's how: https://t.co/GnAOr6pwS8

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Learn more about our ocean technology here: https://t.co/FMHEQBk1SY. (5/5)

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: This is an important phase and we aim to learn a lot about this crucial component (plastic retention) before we can move forward with System 002. (4/5)

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: We tested various plastic intake methods, such as plastic underflow in relation to the screen depth. (3/5)

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: A small team of our engineers - while following social distancing rules and necessary health measures - studied the behavior and impact of plastics in the retention area and the overtopping mechanism as a way to enter plastic in the retention area. (2/5) https://t.co/1NpLwkoT4x

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Ocean system update: one of the main features of our ocean cleanup system we seek to improve is its ability to retain plastic for long time periods (multiple months); so this was the focus of our testing at Maritime Research Institute Netherlands during the past two weeks. (1/5) https://t.co/aKKIslmNJD

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @blueknightPH @mashable We applaud the work of all initiatives and believe they're a beneficial and necessary contribution to cleaning rivers around the world. The main difference of our solution is scalability: The Interceptor is a product that can be placed in the majority of rivers around the world.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @gokiker What an amazing challenge! Thanks for your support, and best of luck to you!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Did you enjoy this conversation? Let us know what you think in the comments below.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text:
Recently, our followers have asked us how our progress is affected by the pandemic circumstances. So, we decided to catch up with some of our teammates to hear it directly from them. Have a listen here: 
https://t.co/ess7aJuZSx

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @IntEngineering Thanks so much for sharing! To learn more about the Interceptor, visit: https://t.co/PaWUnmbChG

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @FigueraMaia It's great that you've volunteered to help, Maia! However, please keep in mind that we recruit volunteers on a needs basis. You will receive a follow-up email should we require your assistance!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @azsam_8 @MinistryofWaste You can find our official partners here: https://t.co/0A3CsYQOBY

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @marokeano Indeed Jose. We believe that it is not a decision of either cleanup or prevention, we need to work on both cleanup AND prevention. That is why we have developed the Interceptor as our solution to river plastic pollution. Read more about it here: https://t.co/PaWUnmbChG

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: In our mission to rid the world’s oceans of plastic, we rely on a thorough understanding of the ocean plastic pollution problem. This is why research is a big part of our journey - and it's something we're happy to do. https://t.co/EaAoE5wErT

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @FlorianTpt The installation of Interceptor 004 (Dominican Republic) will be completed just as soon we can safely return to the Rio Ozama. We hope that will be as soon as possible!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Dan Leahy, CMO and Head of Partnerships at The Ocean Cleanup was interviewed by @Forbes to talk about our projects and how we are looking to partner with innovative brands. Check out the full interview here: https://t.co/47SaNFBjKm

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @BRSBF1 The Great pacific Garbage Patch is three times the size of France. Chasing the plastic with boats would take far too long, be expensive, and emit a lot of carbon into the environment. This is why the ocean currents are the main driver for our technology.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @BrattlandDiane Plastic at the surface is easier to clean than plastic that sinks, but the fate of this fallout is unknown and risks seriously harming ecosystems. Because the plastic sinking is fallout from the surface, it shows that it is more important than ever to act quickly.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text:
The majority (about 90%) of the plastic mass in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch is in the top 5m of the upper 2000m of the water column we sampled; most debris is still found at the surface.

Take a look at the full research results here:
https://t.co/oxic7FhGNI https://t.co/ftyV6Z6HnM

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @FigueraMaia Hello Maia! It's great to hear you'd like to join the team!  You can check out our open intern opportunities here: https://t.co/uCUoGADOKd

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @shaun_dubai Thank you so much for your support! You can find a YouTube video about this research here: https://t.co/JkIV05QZTA

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Read more about the findings from this research here: https://t.co/oxic7FhGNI

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Last week, we shared the results of our research on plastic fallout from the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. One of the key moments of this research process was the deployment of the deep sea sampling equipment. Take a look behind the scenes of this moment: https://t.co/T0GUwRG7tw

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Laudern @BoyanSlat Interceptor 003 is awaiting final paperwork in Vietnam, and the deployment of Interceptor 004 in the Dominican Republic will recommence once it is safe to do so!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @martyaarts @UCSBenioffOcean We hope to eventually be able to deploy Interceptors wherever cleanup is beneficial. However, we recognize that we are not the only solution, and encourage others to help tackle plastic pollution!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @FlorianTpt @UCSBenioffOcean We are aiming to begin the project in early 2021 - stay tuned for further updates!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @RealFrenchWill @UCSBenioffOcean We don't have an exact date for deployment just yet, but the project is expected to be initiated at the beginning of 2021.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @kansas_js @UCSBenioffOcean The Interceptor is indeed a part of the solution - with education and prevention as key factors in dealing with the problem of plastic pollution. Working with local stakeholders, we hope to encourage improvements to overall waste management practices and infrastructure.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @creadev_io @Slade_Lin @UCSBenioffOcean Legislative changes, education, and better waste management infrastructure are some of the challenges we are facing.  Read more in our update here: https://t.co/KW3dwBwGJN

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @AljjackAl @UCSBenioffOcean Great to hear that you'd like to donate - we really appreciate it! You can find information on donating here: https://t.co/CVt4f3Xkx0

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @pictorex @UCSBenioffOcean Education and prevention are indeed key components of removing plastic pollution, but it requires both legislative and behavioral changes.  As a technology company, we have decided to focus on what we know best: technology.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @helioscedeno @UCSBenioffOcean @JosueSanchezEc @CynthiaViteri6 @alcaldiagye We have several locations in Ecuador on our map of 1000 top-polluted rivers that we aim to help tackle. You can see them on our map, here: https://t.co/vwMHpQYqVH

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @caribwoy @UCSBenioffOcean Indeed Julian, this is why it is important for us to deploy an Interceptor! Our research indicated that Hunts Bay, which pours into Kingston Harbour, is Jamaica’s highest polluted waterway, responsible for an estimated 578,000 kg of plastic flowing into the ocean each year!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Slade_Lin @UCSBenioffOcean Good question! The waste handling is managed by our local partners and/or operators of the Interceptor. In some locations, the best available solution - and our minimum requirement for deployment - is a sanitary landfill.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: To find out more about the award, read our update here: https://t.co/w5bQ6OTjTL

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Thanks to the @UCSBenioffOcean, The Ocean Cleanup will be able to deploy an Interceptor in Jamaica's most polluting waterway, responsible for an estimated 578,000 kg (roughly the weight of 80 African elephants) of plastic entering the ocean yearly. https://t.co/IDRHWU3MDz

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Sakutan @UCSBenioffOcean Our aim is to tackle the 1000 most-polluted rivers with the help of the Interceptor, and Cancun is indeed on our map of those places. You can find it here - https://t.co/vwMHpQYqVH

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @mtintner The Ocean Cleanup will continue to focus on the floating fraction of plastics. Since most of it is located between the surface and a depth of five meters, the cleanup system will be designed to clean up only the plastic which is located in this upper layer of the water column.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @BrattlandDiane @UCSBenioffOcean We feel that it's more important then ever to continue moving forward with our mission of clean oceans! We're happy to share a bit of good news with our wonderful supporters, and thank the Benioff Ocean Initiative for getting us one step closer!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: We are excited to announce that @UCSBenioffOcean has awarded The Ocean Cleanup a grant of $1 million to intercept plastic in Jamaica's most polluting waterway. Read more in our latest update: https://t.co/jHbbOvuH14

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Behind the scenes of our study on the fallout of plastic from the Great Pacific Garbage Patch by our Research Scientist Matthias Egger https://t.co/nBVoR34s5x

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @wid244 @SciReports We hope to be able to return to the Great Pacific Garbage Patch in 2021.If you you'd like to receive the latest updates, subscribe to our newsletter: https://t.co/LmvjzRHB5E

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Read the full study published in Scientific Reports here: https://t.co/LCIEgS0dLc

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: This study further confirms the importance of cleaning up the legacy plastic pollution in our oceans as soon as possible.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: How this pollution impacts the fragile and largely undiscovered deep-sea ecosystem remains unknown. The good news is that most of the plastic is still at or close to the surface.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: These findings lead us to believe that microplastic fragments from debris afloat in ocean garbage patches are making their way to the deep-sea, where cleanup is even more difficult, if not impossible.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: First results indicate that 90% of the plastic mass present in the upper 2000 m of the water column below the Great Pacific Garbage Patch is likely concentrated in the first 5 m below the surface.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Findings reveal that plastics present in the water column are the result of floating plastic at the surface slowly breaking down into microplastic particles that sink. In fact, most of the plastics found in our underwater samples were in the size range of 5 mm or smaller. https://t.co/IxdF8YGtj1

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: During an offshore campaign in the summer of 2019, our scientists collected over 12,000 fragments from the water column below the patch and analyzed them to study the vertical extent of plastic pollution in the area.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Today, we published a new study on the fallout of plastic from the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. https://t.co/IFRSEKBdi0

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @codymcdivitt @SciReports The fate of the fallout is unknown. It could be deposited, move horizontally, return to surface, or stay afloat in the water column. The reality is that deep sea life eat things falling from the surface, and if the plastics do sink, these fragments can seriously harm ecosystems.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @GoPro Thank you so much for supporting our mission and helping us capture the incredible moments along the way! To learn more about our mission to rid the worlds oceans of plastic, visit: https://t.co/wFLn7Osqq7

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @codymcdivitt @SciReports While the plastic is breaking down, the GPGP still exists, with our sampling showing that 90% of the plastic mass is in the first 5m of the water column. This reinforces the need for legacy plastic cleanup, as plastic fallout will likely increase contamination of the deep sea.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Today our findings from plastic fallout in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch were published in @SciReports. The results reveal floating plastic is fragmenting into microplastics and likely sinking to the seabed, potentially harming deep-sea life. Read more: https://t.co/oxic7FhGNI

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @pokatoz Happy belated birthday, Wednesday! Thank you so much for your support, and the support of your friends - we really appreciate it!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @calcoworld Thank you so much for your encouragement! Have you heard about what we plan to do with the plastic that we bring back? To find out more, be sure to check out our products page: https://t.co/Mot4tVav41

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: To learn more about this research, check out: https://t.co/onwrKcT7nj

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Over the past two years, we have been studying plastic distribution underneath the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. Keep an eye out, as our results will be published this Wednesday. https://t.co/kqpXQ066YI

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @mashable Thanks so much for sharing! To find out more about the Interceptor - our answer to river plastic pollution - visit: https://t.co/Lpvf1TvzjZ

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @andrea11228717 Interesting idea - you can follow us on our journey from pollution to product to find out what we'll be making - join here: https://t.co/Mot4tVav41

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @keawijkstra That is indeed one part of the solution, but it will not remove the legacy plastic in the ocean. For this plastic, removing it and transforming it into recyclable products is a solution that lets people to support our continuing mission to rid the world's oceans of plastic.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Zeitgeist8281 If we manage to successfully create products from our plastic catch, we expect the product to be revealed in September 2020. Depending on how the journey progresses, and on your country of residence, we aim to get the limited stock products delivered before the end of 2020.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @JMAsays Thanks for your interest Jane. If you would like to donate as a gift for someone, you can through separate donations. Send us a DM and we’ll let you know how.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @JMAsays It is only possible to make one donation for the product per account. You can always donate more but not currently via the product platform. Please note that when donating via the product platform, we will also ask for another donation to be able to receive the product - thanks!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: One of the most frequent questions we hear is “how can I help?". Here is the answer. https://t.co/6mAV8FlVyr

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @FlamsBreton @brutnaturefr @BoyanSlat @changeNOWsummit Good question! The ocean plastic will be transformed into recyclable products to help us sustain our operations, and river waste will be managed by our local partners and/or operators of the Interceptor. Learn more: https://t.co/wDkEcuczMm

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @brutnaturefr @BoyanSlat @changeNOWsummit Thanks so much for sharing! To learn more about The Ocean Cleanup and our mission to rid the world's oceans of plastic, visit: https://t.co/wFLn7Osqq7

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @JerseyTigerFan @GlblCtzn We are a non-profit project, fully reliant on private and corporate donations and sponsorships. You can learn more here: https://t.co/Y15JRb6XoC

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @GlblCtzn Thanks so much for sharing our mission! We returned to the Great Pacific Garbage Patch last year with System 001/B. In October 2019, we confirmed our concept moving forward and caught plastic along the way. System 002 is now in development. Learn more: https://t.co/u4ALiZZEs5

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @tkstephens Keeping plastic out of the oceans is an obsession we share! We are so happy to have you on board this journey from pollution to product.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @AllenAyres @TheLaurenChen While the primary purpose of Mission One (System 001 and 001/B) was to test rather than collect plastic, we were able to collect 60 1m3 bags of plastic. We are now incorporating the learnings into the System 002 design, aiming to launch in 2021.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text:
Happy Earth Day from The Ocean Cleanup 🌎 Our mission is all about this big, blue planet. To learn more about it and how you can help us achieve it, check out:
https://t.co/Y15JRb6XoC

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @aaaaaaahgoeie @BoyanSlat As a non-profit organization, we do not have stock shares to invest in. All of our funds come from private and corporate donations. If you'd like to donate, you can do so here: https://t.co/CVt4f3Xkx0

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @BergijkM Thank you for your support!  With this product, we hope to fund our efforts so we can achieve our mission goal of cleaning the oceans!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @AtelierEnglish Interesting idea! As the Great Pacific Garbage Patch is 3 times the size of France, chasing plastic with boats and nets would take far too long, be very costly and emit a lot of carbon into the environment. This is why the ocean currents are the main driver for our technology.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @rsspx @BoyanSlat As a non-profit, we rely on donations big and small. While you can't buy stocks, you can donate here: https://t.co/CVt4f3Xkx0

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @benalocas Unfortunately, the legacy plastic will not go away on it's own. Our aim is to give this ocean plastic a new life and turn it into something that does not go back into the ocean, but rather helps our cleanup become self-sustaining.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: On its journey from pollution to product, we must sort the plastic by type to be able to effectively recycle it, eventually transforming it into a beautiful, sustainable product: https://t.co/hCVDrzzuIh https://t.co/RQ2OFkk1IY

text:
@BurraOca @BoyanSlat That's the Klang River in Malaysia.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Our mission continues, no matter what…🔊 https://t.co/2Enooz5bjW

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Since launching the Interceptor, one of the most commonly asked questions is what will be done with the extracted river waste. The answer is not as straightforward as it may seem but our aim is to ensure that no waste returns to the environment. https://t.co/KW3dwBwGJN

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @mrlewismitchell @BoyanSlat The Interceptor is no way a replacement for waste management, conscious behavior of plastic production and disposal. Technology can be a catalyst for change, thus by designing technology that tackles plastic pollution, we hope to incentivize rather than disincentivize change.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @joanheiliger Indeed education is an essential piece to the puzzle, and all efforts to prevent and remove plastic from our waterways are most definitely necessary. As we believe technology is a catalyst for change, we developed the Interceptor as our solution for river plastic waste.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: "The Interceptor is a safety net - a supplement - if all else fails." https://t.co/dw2z4TwDqQ

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Me2self Due to the current global situation, Interceptor 004 (Rio Ozama) is currently on hold. Once things improve, we will have a better idea of when we can resume activities to make Interceptor 004 operational.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Taking the learnings from System 001/B, we have now started developing System 002 - which is intended to be our first full scale, fully operational ocean cleanup system. Watch the full video:  https://t.co/dr3ZBesKcL https://t.co/Rj8eIrcWTv

text: @swansandsable As our goal is to make a product that doesn't end up back in the ocean, the product we create will not only be durable, but also recyclable. And while our focus is on cleanup technology, it is undeniable that recycling infrastructure is crucial to the success of our mission

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: This plastic is not any plastic; it has a story, it's traveled from one of the most far-reaching places on Earth. Now that it's on shore, you can be a part of the story, you can own it. Get first access at https://t.co/hCVDrzhTQJ https://t.co/8aZjWHeyJF

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Echopeus We can't give you an exact weight,  but we can tell you that the amount collected in Mission One  was sixty 1m3 sized bags full, roughly the area of 14000 soccer fields. This was an opportunistic by-catch, as Mission One was a only a test system, and not full-sized.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @enviroartist The biggest challenge is our mission itself - to rid the world's oceans of plastic! You can send us a DM if you'd like a more detailed answer!

text: @digo1digo It's great that you want to join the team! We are not actively looking for volunteers in Brazil at the moment, but you can always submit an open application here:  https://t.co/uCUoGADOKd and we will contact you if the need arises. Good luck!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Echopeus While we would love to have a round number - as the ocean plastic is in the process of being dried, cleaned, and sorted, this is a number we don't yet know! You can learn about the material and follow the plastic journey with us here: https://t.co/hCVDrzhTQJ

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @yolanryan @BoyanSlat While the Interceptor is built like a tank with an anchoring system designed to withstand heavy weather conditions, the current flooding has temporarily impacted our operations. We will take our learnings from these exceptional conditions to continuously improve our technologies.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @jojokotey @BoyanSlat It's great that you'd like to join our team! You can always check out our current open positions and volunteer opportunities here: https://t.co/uCUoGADOKd

text: @princeydelic @oregonfootball Thank you for your support - we really appreciate it!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Robert__Stein We have chosen to use a passive System in order to keep our carbon footprint low, but also because the fewer moving parts and complexity, the bigger the chance the equipment will survive the local conditions. Also a passive System results in less potential damage from by-catch.

name: The Ocean Cleanup

text: @az_getaway Yes, we have. However, this would return the carbon in the material we catch to atmospheric carbon (dioxide), which isn't best for global warming. It's also very energy consuming and costly to produce a product with a relatively low value. Not the best route for us at this stage!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @rvaneijk @BoyanSlat Thank you for sharing your photos!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @2Tabooo To reach our ambition of tackling the 1000 most-polluting rivers in 5 years we need operators, local government support, funders, sponsors, etc.! You can also help build our movement by showing us your interests by using the #1000 rivers hashtag.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @2Tabooo It is important to note that Interceptors are not for lease or for sale, but can be sponsored. For each deployment location, we will collaborate with a local operator and governments to ensure it is safely and legally implemented and that its operations are well-maintained.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Butterflycolour @BoyanSlat @UNEP @TIME Thank you for your kind words. We hope you had an amazing Christmas time! Happy 2020.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @shaun_dubai As we are a non-profit registered in the US and The Netherlands, Interceptors cannot be purchased but are sponsored. If you would like to donate you can visit https://t.co/H1hRXGp6AC or join the plastic journey here: https://t.co/ztrbypmdXG  2/2

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @shaun_dubai Interceptors in our pilot program were approximately 700 thousand euros for construction and assembly. However, we expect that once we are in series production, the costs will be lower. Therefore, Interceptors produced in volume will be more cost-efficient. 1/2

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @fussbalex Thank you for your question! There is a possibility of using a second barrier or another Interceptor. The optimal setup is determined on a case-by-case basis, based on flow-velocity, the width of the river, presence of a plastic “hotline”, traffic, proximity to a delta, etcetera.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @mayankg18 Our aim is to tackle the 1000 highest-polluting rivers with the help of the Interceptor in five years’ time from launch. If you want to see where we are targeting next, check out an overview here: https://t.co/vwMHpQYqVH

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @SinghalPranjal @Maersk @MaerskSupply That will be more or less the case, yes! There will be multiple working in different locations, but over time as we continue to learn, we may develop improved versions of the design.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @cheryl69121456 @BoyanSlat Thanks Cheryl! With the end of Mission 001, System 001/B is no longer in the patch. We have now begun to improve the design for System 002 and in the meantime, we have ceased our activities in the GPGP. You can check out volunteering positions here: https://t.co/zgrQOiqK2T

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @krisztinaart @coolearth Thank you so much for your support!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @rtnkamilah 001 is located in the Cengkareng Drain, near St. Nicholas School, in North Jakarta (https://t.co/gibMAhykCN)

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @DwKittilsen @BoyanSlat The little hero we all need!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Who needs a Christmas tree when you have an interceptor to bring some light? We hope to see them cleaning 1000 rivers by 2025. https://t.co/uXatLyuI0m

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @frickeado Good question - and something that we want to avoid at all costs! Our system is therefore equipped with specific sound and light signals that serve as deterrents for turtles and other marine animals.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @bughish This is a difficult figure to determine as we are still testing. While it will be once we scale up, during testing the number of bags we captured was not our key performance indicator. Ultimately, what you see here are the costs/efforts in reaching our goal.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @CREALOGIX Thank you for your support - we really appreciate it!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Gesvalt Thank you for your support! We really appreciate it!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @phbem2019 Happy Holidays to you, too!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Monmoranc We want to give the ocean plastic a new life and turn it into something that does not go back into the ocean. Our team is working with credible partners to recycle the plastic into durable products – join the plastic journey here: https://t.co/ztrbypmdXG

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: You can have exclusive access to the journey from pollution to product. Get on board at https://t.co/hCVDrzhTQJ https://t.co/EASdyLAvoW

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @andrewcrisanto That is a very good question, coming from a well-understood concern. However, we don't have the means to handle government requirements, but we will talk with them about it. If a situation does not meet our minimum requirements, we shall not deploy.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @jacobzur @BoyanSlat Good question! When the barge is out, the shuttle conveyor (“basket” in which the conveyor belt empties) serves as temporary storage. When the barge returns, the collected trash is emptied from the shuttle into the dumpsters. The capacity is sufficient for holding time.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @AndrewF53173428 @DankestHokie We are currently exploring our options to commercialize the ocean plastic so the revenue made would come directly back to The Ocean Cleanup enabling us to scale-up and therefore are not looking into producing material for housing or construction. Thanks for your interest!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @stevewi29193475 Great photo! Thank you for sharing!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Sacasa45 @BoyanSlat There are many ways to help like spreading our mission, reducing your plastic waste and recycling where possible. For a more complete list, please send us a direct message!

text: @DE5ERT_W0LF @BoyanSlat Definitely an amazing animal - from a respectful distance. 😀

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @jariaz10 2/2  and send the confirmation email to the person receiving the gift. They can then create their account. Happy Holidays!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @jariaz10 You can absolutely purchase as a gift!  Simply go to our Products page (https://t.co/ztrbypmdXG) and complete the donation steps with your own e-mail. Once you receive a confirmation e-mail, and are ready to transfer , you can contact us to change the donation details 1/2

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @TopSecretNinjaa We hope to install live video cameras on Interceptors once 003 and 004 are in place - stay tuned!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @SinghalPranjal @Maersk @MaerskSupply Now that we have completed Mission One, we will compile our learnings and begin the process of designing System 002. Because we iterate fast, we will conduct repetitive testing at rapid rates to be able to return to the Great Pacific Garbage Patch as soon as possible.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @DankestHokie We want to give the ocean plastic a new life and turn it into something that does not go back into the ocean. Our team is working with credible partners to recycle the plastic into durable products – join the plastic journey here: https://t.co/ztrbypmdXG

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Last week we showed you our plastic catch from the Great Pacific Garbage Patch (and our plans for it); all the while, the Interceptor in Malaysia has been regularly removing river waste that is being returned to shore via its detachable barge. https://t.co/a3kJeyXuMF

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @BKstandards Hello Will. Once Interceptors 003 and 004 are in place, we hope to set up a live video feed that our supporters can follow. Stay tuned!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @beefcarpacio @BoyanSlat We collect about the same amount by our Interceptors per day, as what the ocean plastic catch we showed onshore in Vancouver on December 12! We are working on live streams and live information for our river activities. Please allow for some time to set this up!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @_BScientific @BoyanSlat Thank you so much for your support! Together we can get rid of the world's oceans of plastic.

text: @Lstreetjournal We love to see your commitment! Thank you so much for joining us on this journey from pollution to product.

text: @PlasticFreeWN We have some ideas about what we would like to make, but as this is the first time we recycle our ocean plastic collected from the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, we first need to understand the plastics’ characteristics, before determining what products we can make.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @ZedMePlz @BoyanSlat Thanks again for supporting The Ocean Cleanup. We are looking forward to experiencing the plastic journey with you!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @codymcdivitt While the primary purpose of Mission One was to test rather than collect plastic we were able to collect 60 1m3 bags of plastic. If you’d like to join us on the plastic journey to find out what the material is like and what the product will be, go here: https://t.co/ztrbypmdXG

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Every piece of plastic extracted from the ocean during System 001/B mission has been logged and tagged to ensure its traceability. A fundamental part of our commitment to bring transparency to the market of products made of ocean plastic. Learn more: https://t.co/hCVDrzhTQJ https://t.co/bYKBSYbmXu

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @TweetByDerek Thanks for your interest in The Ocean Cleanup. We don't have any statistics on specific products or brands. We are currently concentrating on cleaning, which keeps us quite busy in general!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @DevilsA14585280 As System 001/B was smaller it's hard to determine exactly but our models estimate we can clean up 50% in 5 years from full scale launch. While this isn't an individual trip projection, as the GPGP is estimated to contain 80,000 tonnes of plastic we can estimate projected volume.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @ParamoreRocks21 @BoyanSlat Unfortunately, the amount is set to 50 euros or dollars to join the plastic journey. However, the behind the scenes content published will be early access, so you will just need to wait a little longer to see it! If you would like to donate less, go here: https://t.co/CVt4f3Xkx0

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @OpenTechPark @UN In repurposing plastic to product, we can assure you we are working with credible partners, undergoing 3rd-party audits, and taking your best interest into account every step of the way. We guarantee that this will be a durable, recyclable item you can cherish for a long time.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @DevilsA14585280 While the primary purpose of Mission One was to test rather than collect, we were able to collect 60 1m3 bags of plastic. text: @flauwekel Thanks for your support! Any guesses what the product will be?

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @AOrtega7777 We want to give the ocean plastic a new life and turn it into something that does not go back into the ocean. Our team is working with credible partners to recycle the plastic into durable products – join the plastic journey here: https://t.co/ztrbypmdXG

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @premnirmal @BoyanSlat We found that most plastic is filtered by the coast and shoreline. The plastic that makes it offshore is buoyant and highly persistent. As this plastic slowly degrades, it will cause more harm to the environment, therefore we believe it’s necessary to remove this legacy plastic.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @dougy4321 -

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @dougy4321 While the purpose of Mission One was to test rather than collect plastic, we were able to collect 60 1m3 bags of plastic. If you'd like to join us on the plastic journey to find out what the material is like and what the product will be, get on board here: https://t.co/ztrbypmdXG

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: You can have exclusive access to the journey from pollution to product. And when that product is launched, you can be very first in line. Take ocean cleaning into your own hands. Check out: https://t.co/hCVDrzhTQJ https://t.co/rqZLif9HZ5

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @dora_luise @BoyanSlat Thanks for your question! At this time, we have no plans to set up an ocean system in the Mediterranean, as they are designed to work in the 5 major ocean gyres.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @godan9 @BoyanSlat There is no island of trash. The Great Pacific Garbage Patch (GPGP) is an area three times the size of France with plastic dispersed within in. To learn more check out our GPGP video: https://t.co/WenYLo9VXM Cleaning these gyres is what our ocean systems are designed to do.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @LadySayFuckALot @BoyanSlat While the primary purpose of Mission One was to test rather than collect plastic, we collected sixty 1m3 bags of plastic. If you'd like to join us on the plastic journey to find out what the material is like, and what the product will be get on board here: https://t.co/ztrbypmdXG

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @short_guts According to samples collected during our 2015 Mega Expedition and the “Wilson” mission in 2018, we expect to have around 90-95% HDPE (such as fishing nets) and 5-10% PP. From the 2015 expedition we also know that gyre plastic has a 40-45% fishing gear ratio.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: You can be one of the first to get access to the first items ever made from Great Pacific Garbage Patch plastic and will get an exclusive front row seat to the journey from pollution to product. Get on board with us: https://t.co/hCVDrzhTQJ https://t.co/NpyQyryAmJ

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @ArjunNath6 It's great that you'd like to join in! At the moment we have open volunteer opportunities for multimedia positions. You can check out our other open job opportunities here: https://t.co/uCUoGADOKd

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: To bring transparency to the market of products that are labeled to be made of ocean plastic, we asked @DNVGL to launch a standard to verify that our ocean plastic is indeed 100% plastic removed from the ocean. https://t.co/LEKYkVMzT8

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @EnvironmentWhi1 While the main purpose of Mission One (System 001 and 001/B) was to test rather than collect plastic, we were able to collect 60 1m3 bags of plastic. If you'd like to join us on the plastic journey to find out what the product will be get on board here: https://t.co/ztrbypmdXG.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: The first plastic has arrived on shore. Next stop: September 2020, when we aim to launch the first product made out of plastic from the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. Learn more: https://t.co/hCVDrzhTQJ https://t.co/DCBiqceucy

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: 🔴LIVE: 'First plastic on shore. Next stop: September 2020, when we aim to launch the product. Those first to sign up, get exclusive access to the journey from pollution to product and can get a spot in line to have access to this unique product." https://t.co/Mot4tVav41

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: 🔴 LIVE: "These bags hold the key to making the cleanup self-sustaining. Because we’re going to recycle this plastic. And we’re going to turn this trash into a beautiful, sustainable product that you can buy." https://t.co/44OCSOTXGH

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: 🔴 LIVE: "For this cleanup to happen, it needs to be both technically and financially viable. Once these cleanup systems are out there, we need a model through which the cleanup will be able to continue… by paying for itself." https://t.co/PdFRdF5Yv0

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text:
Join us now as we share our plans to turn the problem of ocean plastic into a solution and how you can take part.
https://t.co/lIFzySFBQb

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @dreaminspiresHL Congratulations to the winner! It's always great to hear about young people getting involved in a cause that we are so passionate about. Way to go!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @JMAsays Marine life (such as fish) are a top priority. We work with experts, use deterrent devices, and much more! Also if any marine life is endangered we will halt operations until it is safe.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @fleur1963 The plastic has been brought back Vancouver, Canada. Always dare to ask - and we will tell you, but on Dec 12th. Tune into the livestream here: https://t.co/lIFzySFBQb

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Bringing plastic back to land has been our dream ever since The Ocean Cleanup was founded. And now we are here. Tune in on December 12th. https://t.co/afEZfMRMws

text: @ximemoraga Hi Xime, thanks for your interest in The Ocean Cleanup. Unfortunately,  we don't have any plans to visit the Easter Island area in the near future. If you were looking for a volunteer position, you can always check out our careers page here: https://t.co/uCUoGADOKd

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @PamenRapado Hard work and dedication are essential for tackling such a huge problem! Thank you for your kind words and for supporting us. Be sure to tune in on December 12th for some exciting updates.

text: @Rocks62Rocks Thank you for your kind words!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text:
@BakaKarasu Good question! According to our ocean trials, our technology is catching microplastics down to 1mm in size. Read more about our recent advancements here: https://t.co/u4ALiZZEs5    
Also, be sure to tune in on December 12th for some exciting updates!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: It is sorted, put out to dry, weighed, and tagged. On board, the ocean plastic is processed and classified before it is ready to go on shore. Make sure to tune in on December 12th to see what we will do with it next. https://t.co/D2gsHYdo4p

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @SinghalPranjal @BoyanSlat Thanks for applying! As we receive a number of applicants each day, we are only able to reach out on a needs basis. We'll get back to you if ever the need arises!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @blokchainreport @BoyanSlat Thank you so much for offering your support! Check out our Careers page for all open volunteer positions: https://t.co/QPmqRUs5xI

text: There's nothing like that moment when you realize for the first time that you're catching plastic. Find out more about its destination on December 12th https://t.co/HrCG9M3QXn

text: @randomcomment4 Thank you! We strive to keep our community as informed as possible.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @getsavvynavvy @Zizooboats @nauticed Thank you so much for the support! We are so humbled to have amazing supporters like yourselves.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @hobisluver Great to hear that you want to get involved. There are many ways to help like spreading our mission, reducing your plastic waste and recycling where possible. For a more complete list, please send us a direct message!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: On December 12, from Vancouver Harbour in Canada, for the first time we will show our plastic catch on shore. We will share our plans on how we will turn this problem into a solution and how you can take part. Tune in on 12 December to find out. https://t.co/lIFzySFBQb

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @AndrePavatoni @BoyanSlat For now we're only listed in the US, but we might consider registering on the German Amazon site in the future. Until then, you can support us here: https://t.co/CVt4f3Xkx0

text: @Gayatri_3443 The Interceptor can currently collect plastic pieces as small as bottle caps and straws. We are optimizing the barrier and extraction to be able to capture smaller plastic.   Thanks for your interest!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @ukgeneco Thank you for your support - it's much appreciated!

text: @nesiawalandouw @CarelFrankenfry @BoyanSlat We can't wait either! Any guesses on what we might do with the plastic?

text: @BrattlandDiane @BoyanSlat That is the plan - 1000 in 5 years, in fact! But will that be what we do with the collect ocean plastic on Dec 12? Be sure to tune in to find out!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: What will we do with our ocean plastic? On December 12th, we will share news about this frequently asked question and update you on the Great Pacific Garbage Patch cleanup. https://t.co/6vl3Ufc13y

text: @NewScience101 Thank you so much for spreading our mission - we are so grateful!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: System 001/B was designed to help us learn more about our ocean cleanup technology. In June, we sat down with Reijnder, who was with the crew aboard the Maersk Transporter, to discuss the plans for this system and what lay ahead. https://t.co/oscE66DUMJ

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @anniek1963 Our goal is to tackle the 1000 highest-polluting rivers with the help of the Interceptor!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @SinghalPranjal @BoyanSlat Not each of them - with technology iteration, we are always looking for how we can improve. So each Interceptor will not have 2.0 etc. but will be a new number for example 005. An example of a difference was changing from collecting the debris in bags vs. bins!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Still wondering what an Interceptor is? Let the team explain it to you. https://t.co/6kjZoGHmQr

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text:
@SinghalPranjal @BoyanSlat Thank you for reaching out!
When we talk about Interceptor 002, we refer to the Interceptor deployed in Malaysia. Interceptor 2.0 refers to the design iteration. Interceptor in Jakarta is 1.1, 2.0 in Malaysia, and the next one will be 3.0.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: .@DeloitteNL studied the financial impact of plastic pollution on national economies. Do you want to find out how your country is affected? Click on the map to see the calculated costs. https://t.co/VQjJJWU9JE

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Tombledore @KLM We appreciate your effort in helping us with our mission, many thanks!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Here's a look back at the journey of our ocean systems. Check out the timeline on the page to see milestones from October 2017 to the latest return to shore, and even a glimpse at future plans. https://t.co/Gw0jl5sU1k https://t.co/Q3rq2Vg0rn

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @NLintheUSA Thank you so much for supporting The Ocean Cleanup!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @11krishnasingh @BoyanSlat Thank you for your offer of support. Please send email to info@theoceancleanup.com and a member of our team will respond promptly!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Bobbie89625862 @maritiemmuseum Interceptor 004 will not be operational while it stays at the museum as a guest. The dock where it is stationed has no water flow which is needed for our technology to run and we hope to be on our way to the Dominican Republic as soon as possible.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @WolfIgmc4 @BibaBuzemann @maritiemmuseum Both great questions! Before heading to the Dominican Republic to start cleaning - Interceptor 004 will remain at the museum while all logistics are put into place. We will start cleaning as soon as possible!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @iLaura_B @maritiemmuseum We couldn't agree more! Interceptor 004 will be parked at the museum until all logistics are in place to bring it to its more permanent location - the Dominican Republic. Stay tuned!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @stefanvdeijk @KLM Thanks for wanting to support us! You can get more information about air mile donations on our website here: https://t.co/CVt4f3Xkx0 and scrolling to the FAQ at the bottom.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @waarom192 We have plans to set up a live camera stream once Interceptors 003 and 004 are in place. Hang in there!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @nicnowak We are an NPO,  therefore the Interceptor is not commercially available. Placing an Interceptor requires the cooperation of local operators and governments to ensure that they are safely and legally implemented and maintained.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @kgokongt @LACoPublicWorks To make sure e-mails reach the right person, they must be sent through specific channels. We can assure you they will be forwarded to the right person! Thank you for your patience.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @kgokongt @LACoPublicWorks We appreciate your passion and enthusiasm! We are still working through emails sent following our Interceptor launch and a member of the team will get back to you as soon as possible.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @kgokongt @LACoPublicWorks The best way to involve your local government is to create awareness by contacting them directly, whether via email, letters, or other means. Thanks for your interest!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: On Friday, we signed an agreement with @LACoPublicWorks to deploy an Interceptor in Ballona Creek next year. https://t.co/OlYSgQ2KS1

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Through years of research into riverine plastic and its behaviors, we have sought to understand the fundamental principles of plastic transport from rivers to oceans. https://t.co/eoGdgEvquv

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @wantstobeajerk Thank you so much for your support!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @laafrr__ The purpose of System 001/B’s mission hasn't been to collect plastic. Our focus has been to test and learn about the system. It is important that we overcome the known challenges before we focus on mass plastic extraction but naturally plan to extract more plastic ASAP.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @MCR_WL While the Interceptor is designed for rivers, our ocean system, System 001/B, is designed to clean plastic within the Great Pacific Garbage Patch (which not the location mentioned in the article.) System 001/B is currently on its way home. Stay tuned for future developments!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @RobMoran78 Aww thanks, Rob! What a nice thing to say. We're looking forward to sharing our findings with the world on December 12. Stay tuned!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: The crew has begun the return to shore with System 001/B. With this system, we have confirmed the core concept of the cleanup technology design and have completed all planned trials. We will now look to the next big steps for 2020 - find out more on December 12. https://t.co/wHkjje6aeP

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @PlasticOceansUS Thank you so much for supporting The Ocean Cleanup!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @jp_dutch System 001/B is smaller in order to make testing cycles shorter and more convenient but is still large enough to ensure validity of the tests. Learn more on our Technology page: https://t.co/g2adavZVpR

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Gerhard_DMU Prevention is indeed a necessary part of the solution, but it is a complex issue that requires legislative and behavioral change. As we believe technology is a catalyst for change, we developed the Interceptor as our solution for river plastic waste.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @WILLIAMDIXON52 Isn't it great? The song is Animus Vox by The Glitch Mob

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @TinchoHimura @Ridd1e We have found two live animals in the debris during testing and returned both to continue their river journey! Our third-party environmental impact assessments indicated that our systems pose negligible risks to the environment and are removing waste that harms their environment.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: RT @BoyanSlat: The Interceptor at night looks like something out of Blade Runner https://t.co/LjyWDbRQJ9
retweet_text: The Interceptor at night looks like something out of Blade Runner https://t.co/LjyWDbRQJ9

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: While we were introducing the Interceptor to the world, our offshore crew has continued to oversee ongoing operations in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. Here's a look back at System 001/B and the team, trialing plastic collection 1200 nautical miles from shore: https://t.co/r7wTvscBvp

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @chuckruff106 @BoyanSlat Maaaaybe.......

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @yuszuri You can always fill in an open application with us. Then we will have your information on file. Thanks again!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @yuszuri Thanks for your interest in The OceanCleanup! You can find out more information about our job and volunteering opportunities here: https://t.co/uCUoGADOKd

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @acrossabluesea @BoyanSlat What a charming story! So glad to hear you and your mother are supporters.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @DennySabah @hannahh @ChristineSheare @brucenilles We really appreciate your support! Not sure we've been compared to a vacuum before, though.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @AmmirHamdan That teddy bear really stole the show! He wanted to see the Interceptor up close, but we're not sure we approve of his methods.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @NorSuhailaMRA Hello Missu. It's great to hear you'd like to be a part of our mission. You can find a link to all of our open positions and volunteer opportunities here: https://t.co/uCUoGADOKd

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @hollandhauke @DLFNachrichten Currently, our focus is to tackle the 1000 most polluted rivers in 5 years! However, @thegreatbubblebarrier has just launched its own great initiative in Amsterdam. We all need to be part of the solution. Thanks for your question!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @neopolyglot @BoyanSlat We are sorry to hear that India is affected by plastic pollution. Our ambition is to deploy Interceptors into the highest polluting rivers in the world and India is on our radar. We are working to clean asap - stay tuned for future developments!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @DanielHart2019 As we can identify the natural accumulation areas in a river, the barrier does not have to span the entire width of the river. We can then place the Interceptor in a location that prevents the majority of plastic flowing through the river, while still allowing vessels to pass.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @ibm2ibm Great work Michael! Nice shirt by the way.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @monymiamor @BoyanSlat Hello Monica, thank you so much for wanting to support us! There are many ways to help like spreading our mission, reducing your plastic waste and recycling where possible. For a more complete list, please send us a direct message!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @joaquinmorenook By carrying out third-party environmental impact assessments, we established that our systems do not post any significant risks to the environment. Our systems have been deemed environmentally friendly as we are actually removing waste that pollutes the animals' environment!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @MCNnetwork2015 No negative interactions have been observed between the system and passing animals. Our third-party environmental impact assessments indicated that our systems do not pose significant risks to the environment. We are actually removing waste that pollutes the animals' environment!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @tugweltp The system does not separate the organic matter from the inorganic waste, but we do once it is onshore! Once separated we work with local operators to determine if it would be beneficial to release the organic material to continue its path or if another method is more desirable.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @samd_speaks @BoyanSlat @FirhadHakim @Tanmoy_Fetsu We are sorry to hear that India is affected by plastic pollution. Our ambition is to deploy Interceptors into the highest polluting rivers in the world and the Ganga is on our radar. We are working to clean asap - stay tuned for future developments!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @D_cence This was a track specially created for our unveil event - not currently available to the public. Sorry!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: That moment when you have to give a serious presentation and you are interrupted by a teddy bear. If this bear is yours, do feel free to reach out to us. https://t.co/Ii3bijSD3x

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @basiclaser As many as it will take to reach our goal and beyond! Our goal is to tackle 1000 of the world's most polluting rivers in 5 years, so as many as it takes to get there!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Raserball @BoyanSlat All we have to say is that where we're going, we don't need roads.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Unicowsoap @BoyanSlat That is precisely what the Interceptor is! The river flow helps guide waste to the conveyor belt, where it is transferred into one of six containers on a removable barge. We aim to deploy Interceptors wherever cleanup is beneficial. You can read more here: https://t.co/Hm7ZZ8nGOA

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Virus_Vicky @Benioff Plastic cleaning! The Interceptor is The Ocean Cleanup's solution for river plastic waste. Our mission is to rid the world's oceans of plastic and to do so we must intercept it before it reaches the ocean. To learn more check out our website: https://t.co/VsmIZ1uc6f

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @AndrePavatoni @BoyanSlat We are already an option! You can find us under "The Ocean Cleanup North Pacific Foundation".

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @SampleOf1 @plasticmakers It does! Our recent testing has shown that we can catch and retain plastics as small as 1mm.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @tinkewk We will be working with the best available local waste management, and if that infrastructure is not in place, we will look to establish partners with solutions that are affordable, sustainable, and comply with local regulations.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @SinghalPranjal @BoyanSlat If such changes are observed, over the long-term, actions will be taken to ensure the Interceptor continues to capture waste efficiently.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Shatasha2 @CNET @Abovo42 thanks for your support! Observations thus far have shown that fish simply swim around it. There have been no negative interactions observed so far between the system and wildlife!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @urvyam For the pilot program, the costs of construction and assembly was approximately 700 thousand euros. Once we are in series production, we expect this cost to go down.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @RexFut @plasticmakers In addition to larger debris, the current screen can catch plastics down to 1mm in size.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @premell @BoyanSlat River life is a priority! Third-party environmental impact assessments have shown the Interceptor has a negligible negative impact on the surrounding environment. Fish can swim around it, and we've observed birds using it as a landing point!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @tommysoffi @BoyanSlat With proper maintenance, we expect Interceptors to last approximately 20 years.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @tespeleta @BoyanSlat Great question! This was answered in Boyan's AMA - you can find a summary here: https://t.co/hJXhCErz7d

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Tykils @BoyanSlat We hope to have a live stream up once Interceptors 003 and 004 have been deployed. Stay tuned!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @StephenNancekiv @BoyanSlat Organic matter will be separated once the waste is taken onshore. From there, local operators can decide whether to return the beneficial organic debris - should they see fit!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text:
@RobinVSchendel @BoyanSlat You are correct - intercept and then process! The Interceptor itself cannot distinguish between waste types, with sorting done onshore. The percentage of organic/inorganic varies per location, and we are currently 
researching to get a better understanding of the collected waste.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @wdfisgoinon @BoyanSlat Thanks for your support! Based on our models, Asia does tend to have a generally lower level of waste management and a higher population - both of which contribute to river pollution. It is not one person or country's mess - we all need take responsibility and work together.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Danny_T1981 @BoyanSlat All environmental impact assessments have shown that the Interceptor has negligible impact on the environment. From our observations, the Interceptor is simply a bird's palace to perch on!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @fazleyff At this time there are no public visits for the Interceptor in Malaysia, but you can see it on the Klang River from the Kota bridge (https://t.co/gokxvBhYz6). Help is always welcome! Take a look at our careers page, where we have volunteer application (https://t.co/uCUoGAVpBL).

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @prasant_c We're working on it. We hope to have it up as soon as possible - stay tuned!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @grb090423 Thank you for reaching out and sharing your concern. During testing we found two live animals in the debris before returning both to continue their river journey. Third-party environmental impact assessments show that our systems pose no serious risks to the environment.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @MayorCloudCity @plasticmakers The main driver behind our cleanup technology is to stop plastic from causing further destruction to the ocean and its inhabitants. The Interceptor is not a replacement for waste management and infrastructure, nor conscious behavior of plastic usage.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: With the recent announcement of our river cleanup technology, the Interceptor, @BoyanSlat took to Twitter to answer some of the internet’s questions about this newly revealed project. https://t.co/hJXhCErz7d https://t.co/ndRf2KdvFN

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @HomesInPBC @CNET The Interceptor is a system that concentrates and extracts waste from rivers. The waste is transferred onto a shuttle and into one of six containers on a barge. Once full, the waste is transferred to a local waste management facility.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @dr_jhbowers @plasticmakers We found that most plastic is filtered by the coast and shoreline. The plastic that makes it offshore is buoyant and highly persistent. As this plastic slowly degrades, it will cause more harm to the environment, therefore we believe it’s necessary to remove this legacy plastic.
