text: @SalleeSpeaks Thank you for your support - we really appreciate it!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @juliettelucie It’s autonomous, so it requires little human involvement and it does not require laborers to handle dirty or harmful river debris. It has also been designed for mass production, so it can be manufactured, assembled, and installed more cost- and time efficiently.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @juliettelucie The main differentiator between this solution and the Interceptor™ is scalability: The Interceptor™ is a product that can be placed in the majority of rivers around the world.

text: Say hello to The Ocean Cleanup Interceptor. Our solution for preventing river pollution from entering the ocean. https://t.co/PhWcaBwLPe

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @AlasinLuquez @jmagreen Hello Alasin. For testing, we deployed Interceptors™ in specific locations. Now that we are ready to launch, our ambition is, with the help of local governments and operators, to deploy Interceptors into rivers all over the world that can benefit from this technology.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @BinStrap Hello. We applaud the work of other initiatives. The main differentiator between this solution and the Interceptor™ is scalability: The Interceptor™ is a product that can be placed in the majority of rivers around the world.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @MacMac_PL Hello. Anywhere the Interceptor will be installed, we will look for the best available local waste management solutions. When options are insufficient, our aim is to work with new partners towards sustainable, affordable, and regulation compliant solutions.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @MMkJones @BoyanSlat Anywhere the Interceptor will be installed, we will look for the best available local waste management solutions. When options are insufficient, our aim is to work with new partners towards sustainable, affordable, and regulation compliant solutions.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @DeGrApoth @volkskrant Thank you for reaching out to The Ocean Cleanup. We appreciate your support! The Interceptor is designed to be scaleable, so that each river's unique needs can be met.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @tjerubbaal @tictoc @BoyanSlat According to our ocean trials, our technology is catching microplastics down to 1mm in size. Read more about our recent advancements here: https://t.co/u4ALiZZEs5

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @brinkblok Ensuring we do not harm river life is a top priority! We commissioned third-party environmental impact assessments which concluded that in locations where an Interceptor is deployed, the negative impact is negligible. For each deployment, we will conduct additional assessments.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @lebearpolare Thank you for your support!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: First images of Interceptor 002 cleaning in Malaysia. https://t.co/RDZioYgcUk

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Today, we unveiled the invention to prevent the unrelenting flow of plastic pollution into the world’s oceans: https://t.co/3Xgd5D7Ij4

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @AtelierEnglish @Sustainable2050 We kept this project under the radar to avoid raising false expectations. Our objective was to be able to announce a project that was working. Now that we have two systems operating, we believed it was the appropriate time to unveil this with the wider public.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @itzukaaa Hello, Yes, one Interceptor has been deployed in Jarkarta, Indonesia.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @digihans Anywhere the Interceptor will be installed, we will look for the best available local waste management solutions. When options are insufficient, our aim is to work with new partners towards sustainable, affordable, and regulation compliant solutions.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Ashton15Mark Thanks for wanting to support us! Please visit our support page to learn more: https://t.co/onqiy3jiPm

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @floragraham We applaud the work of the Thames Initiative and believe it is a beneficial and necessary contribution to cleaning rivers. The main differentiator between this solution and the Interceptor is scalability.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @rstwohee The river monitoring devices and detection algorithm are currently optimized to detect plastic debris floating at the river water surfaces. However, we know the majority of plastics are at the surface - read more about it in this study: https://t.co/sG7Z939Bwf

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Mads_Skipper Hello. Ensuring we do not harm river life is a top priority! We commissioned third-party environmental impact assessments which concluded that in all locations where an Interceptor™ is deployed, the negative impact is negligible. We will conduct additional assessments as needed.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @AJ___Long Hi AJ, Thanks for your interest! For more information, please go to our website : https://t.co/lRSo5Bbo47

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Interceptor™ 001 is already cleaning in Indonesia, and Interceptor™ 002 is cleaning in Malaysia. This used to be one of the heaviest polluting rivers in the world! Our goal is to tackle #1000rivers in 5 years’ time. https://t.co/UnqKlW8u2f

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: The Interceptor™ is internet-connected. When it's almost full, it automatically sends a text message to local operators to come and collect the waste. https://t.co/N3LR4Z8HTx

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Here's a demonstration of our river cleanup system intercepting plastic. Disclaimer: no rubber ducks where harmed in the making of this livestream. https://t.co/OE49pJJF1R

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: We call it the Interceptor™. This system is anchored to the riverbed and makes use of the natural flow of the river to collect plastic. https://t.co/nWdqGZFqac

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: What we need is a product: one integrated system you can bring anywhere in the world, install within days and that just works. That’s what we need to close the tap, and it doesn’t exist… Until today. https://t.co/7ZZbnPUafw

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: 1000 rivers are responsible 80% of river plastic pollution. You can see the details on this interactive map: https://t.co/vwMHpQYqVH https://t.co/pYjaQWQTev

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: So where is all this plastic coming from? The answer, it turns out, is rivers. Rivers are like the arteries that carry the trash from land to sea. https://t.co/PbDiRPIvCU

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: To rid the ocean of plastic, what we need to do is two things: clean up the legacy pollution, and close the tap, which means preventing more plastic from reaching the ocean in the first place. https://t.co/YMyKqq48xK

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: “Today we’ll be sharing with you how we’re going to close the tap.” Boyan Slat is taking the stage during our live unveiling. https://t.co/uNrfpYsUfM

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Join us now as we unveil our new breakthrough invention for solving plastic pollution.  https://t.co/lgWJI4sHR6

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @dnnslmr There will be individuals in The Ocean Cleanup sweaters and hats with signs that will lead you to the bus, to the right of the station when you are exiting.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @JesseOnslow Hi Jesse, Event registration is now closed. Please feel free to tune in to the livestream at : www,https://t.co/8DpYlggplj

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: With our sponsor @southpoleglobal, we compensate for all event-related emissions. South Pole is also helping us compensate for the CO2 emissions of vessel transport for System 001+001/B. Find out more about taking climate action on: https://t.co/LqptwYfqfn https://t.co/rxBcLvM471

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text:
"I don't think anyone is expecting this..." 
Get ready to tune in for today's live unveiling at https://t.co/lgWJI4sHR6 https://t.co/UWPm2PpC4b

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Rjshapiro Hi Rochelle. We want to give the plastic a new life and turn it into something that does not go back into the ocean. Our team is working with credible partners to recycle the plastic into durable products - stay tuned!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @battielove @plasticmakers We have a vessel stationed nearby the system for 24/7 monitoring, work with experts to reduce risks, have devices such as lighting to deter wildlife and if marine life is observed endangered by our system, we will halt testing until safe conditions have been restored.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @authorrochelle @plasticmakers @Tess_blue815 Thank you, we appreciate your support.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Si_Goldsmith78 Thanks for your interest. System 001/B was intended to test various modifications and the overall concept. We will likely continue testing through November, but we will focus our next iteration for longevity in the patch and endurance for harsher ocean conditions.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @powerFPC @BoyanSlat We appreciate your interest and support! According to our ocean trials, our technology is catching microplastics down to 1mm in size. Read more about our recent advancements here: https://t.co/u4ALiZZEs5

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @sakari22 It's difficult to date ocean plastics, there is no technology that identifies how long plastic has been in the ocean. The protocol we have in place to estimate the age of plastic objects, is to look at clues such as labels, production dates or organisms that have grown on them.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: In 10 days we will be unveiling our new, breakthrough invention for solving plastic pollution. The event will be livestreamed, subscribe now. https://t.co/lgWJI4sHR6

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @TheDarcBird @Nepsy_Asudra @plasticmakers @santori_lisa Hi there, System 001/B was intended to test various modifications and the overall concept. We will likely continue testing through November, but we will focus our next iteration for longevity in the patch and endurance for harsher ocean conditions.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @realAPV @LaraGStreiff Hi Alex, We want to give the plastic a new life and turn it into something that does not go back into the ocean. Our team is working with credible partners to recycle the plastic into durable products. Check out our website for the latest updates. https://t.co/gQZmVX6BWf

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @JordanTomten Hi Jordan, the current screen size (3 meters) will be able to catch anything from a millimeter-sized plastics to large discarded fishing nets (ghost nets) up to several meters in size. To learn more about our system check out our technology page: https://t.co/xYP4AG6cCY.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: While we're in preparation for October 26th, here's a shot of our offshore team inspecting some of the plastic catch. https://t.co/p2sZJgnanQ

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @epicvoicebrony @plasticmakers Thank you for interest, we want to give the plastic a new life and turn it into something that does not go back into the ocean. Our team is working with credible partners to recycle the plastic into durable products - stay tuned!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @nunesinc @BoyanSlat There are many ways to help like spreading our mission, reducing your plastic waste and recycling where possible. For a more complete list, please send us a direct message!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @kelsimarie91 Hi Kelsi. We are sorry to hear about the terrible effects of Hurricane Dorian. We would have loved to help however, our technology is designed to be deployed in circulating ocean gyres, not closer to shore.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: On Wednesday at 10am CET we will go live to share an important update about our cleanup system in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. Tune in to hear the news firsthand and participate in a Q&A with Boyan Slat and the team. https://t.co/eQm1dKEVVV https://t.co/aj1OKmemRu

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: When they realized a dolphin might be entangled in the ghostnet, our offshore team switched into rescue mode. https://t.co/ZFP53SCSdG

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Right now the weather in the GPGP is preventing the team from completing screen modifications on System 001/B. While we wait for safer conditions, here is a quick recap of what we conceptually achieved so far and the one box left to be ticked on this mission. https://t.co/KHe4c3ovna

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @BinStrap @BoyanSlat Both source reduction and cleanup are needed! It is not a question of choosing one or the other, rather doing both. The plastic that is in the ocean has shown that it is persistent. Before they break down into dangerous microplastics, we need to remove it from the ocean.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @BazLecocq Thank you so much for your feedback, keep it coming - we are working hard on improving this and our response time overall!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Why we need to clean the oceans. Find out more about our latest research: https://t.co/VFSt4936qo https://t.co/cvYRgVtIKS

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Solving the mystery of the missing ocean plastic. Find out more about our latest research: https://t.co/VFSt4936qo https://t.co/Hw5TQzqI4V

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Hundred of thousands of tons of plastic float at the ocean surface, yet millions of tons enter annually. So, where's the missing plastic? Our paper published today offers a new explanation that ends up pointing to the need for cleanup and source reduction: https://t.co/VFSt4936qo

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: This design is made of 2 components: the screen which you can see in these pictures and the new removable retention system - aka cod-end - which will be connected to the central frame and allow for efficient extraction procedures. Testing will resume after installation. 2/2 https://t.co/8J9Dlr8Mj9

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Today the offshore crew is expecting to complete the installation of the new screen, aimed at addressing the overtopping issue. 1/2 https://t.co/gscr6w2JIc

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: A few weeks ago, we caught up on deck with our mechanical engineer in the middle of the ongoing System 001/B campaign to get his first impression after a week testing in slow down configuration. https://t.co/htpZtQQYqv

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: We’re excited to share that we’ve been selected as 1 of 5 winners of the Macquarie 50th Anniversary Award. The $10 million (AUD) Award funding will help us to design and assemble our next cleanup system and start scaling up.  Read more: https://t.co/oZsekcsOfp #Macquarie50Award https://t.co/gzf9DjzAFe

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Special delivery -- the new screen designed to solve our overtopping issue arrived today. Since the Maersk Transporter will be out of the field for resupplies and crew change in the next two weeks, installation is expected soon after its return. https://t.co/RiQ1AyVCsZ

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Getting closer to cleaning the oceans. https://t.co/2Z5q321SAe

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Ciaran751 Thanks, 160m.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: After a 6-week testing campaign, our main technical challenge is solved by modifying the system to move at a consistent speed through the plastic. The slow-down configuration was most effective in the trials. We now address our next challenge... Read more: https://t.co/rNdOBHrsuy

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Testing campaign has now been completed. Results to be shared next week. https://t.co/jvEgMD7VFB

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: In an extended discussion, @BoyanSlat and Technology Manager, Arjen discuss the intricacies of engineering and testing System 001/B and how we aim to reach proof of technology with this cleanup system. https://t.co/OAq1WeglRV

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: You're not seeing double. The @Maersk Launcher and Transporter are both in the middle of the patch for crew shift 1 and shift 2 handover. With that complete, the 1st crew is heading home on the Launcher, while the 2nd will continue the trials with System 001/B. Great work, team. https://t.co/5DmxuvgzBH

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @ericdgraham We first need to complete the System 001/B testing program before making any conclusions. Stay tuned for an update in the next few weeks!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Meet EVE, our @AutoNautUSV - the autonomous research vessel that joins every offshore crew and helps monitor marine life around the cleanup systems. EVE also collects wave and current data and other atmospheric and water parameters. https://t.co/LfssA3vRxy

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Over the last week, the offshore crew has changed the configuration of the system to begin trialing speeding up the system. Using these large lifting bags, we will conduct multiple tests to learn more about this potential modification to the design. https://t.co/ekLEDZMBPM

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: The parachute sea anchor is the last test in our series of decelerating the system. Sea conditions were rough yesterday, and, yet, no complications have been observed. Results are underway, but the crew will move to the configurations to accelerate the system in the coming days. https://t.co/M13cKmFy69

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @TashDins Check out our Careers page for all openings: https://t.co/uCUoGADOKd

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: The crew has conducted the first two tow tests and they are now testing the parachute sea anchor, all aimed at slowing down the system. Data is being processed by HQ, but the tests are running smoothly and the weather has been favorable. We'll update after the campaign concludes. https://t.co/UoSZ2odQNX

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Welcome to the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. It looks like we are in the right spot to test our system. https://t.co/l0qNC6TG16

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Over the coming weeks, we will perform various tests to slow down or speed up the system. Today the team will start the first test to attempt slowing down the system. https://t.co/lVGcnSZFWe

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Speed is key for The Ocean Cleanup to return to the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. This system was built in four months and we are now ready to begin testing our modifications. https://t.co/qDDkzTSfSy

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @joncowen Progressing well, check out our mission plan to see what is next: https://t.co/DIgZ02EyDM

name: The Ocean Cleanup

text: @MeSoShauny_ @BoyanSlat The collected plastic will be brought back to shore and recycled into durable products to help further fund our scale up. Stay tuned!

text: Some of our team members received training from NOAA to rescue, retrieve, and, if applicable, determine cause of death of marine animals. This turtle had only lived in the wild for one year and is now an important reminder of why cleanup is necessary. https://t.co/OOFXDGIBr5

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: After only four months of design, procurement, and assembly, the crew is now on their way to the Great Pacific Garbage Patch with the upgraded System 001/B. Time to put it to the test. https://t.co/wbUUvrihbh

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Before launching System 001/B this week, we tested the parachute sea anchor that will be used for slowing down the system. At low speed, it performed as planned with satisfactory results. We are now green-lighted to test with the system in the patch. More details in coming weeks. https://t.co/LTmSfVtlIA

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: During the four months that System 001 was deployed, our team, together with third-party experts, monitored the environment and how our technology interacts with it. This is how they did it and what they learned from these efforts. https://t.co/xVnhlWARFZ

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: For the 116 days that System 001 was offshore, we conducted extensive environmental monitoring efforts. Initial results show minimal effects on marine life and we will continue this important work when we head back with System 001/B. Read our results here: https://t.co/6aNt8r5lYi

We’re heading back to the Great Pacific Garbage Patch in June to test our upgraded system designs. Here is all you need to know about it.
https://t.co/OUib98rVdF

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Using the learnings from System 001, the team has now completed the design upgrades. This June we will head back to the Great Pacific Garbage Patch with System 001/B to trial these modifications, aiming to reach proof of technology. Learn more here: https://t.co/xD9ZnVCY9P

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Over the last months, the team has been developing options that could help solve the system’s plastic retention challenge. We’re now preparing to test those options in the garbage patch through a more modular approach. We aim to relaunch in June. More details in the coming weeks. https://t.co/ExRlUjfgPE

text: @JZA We are currently not accepting cryptocurrency donations, we apologize for any inconvenience and thank you for your support!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @dproffit Finding these whales in this accumulation zone confirms the risk of whales encountering plastic in the patch. Check out our full blog, and refer to the Sighting 3 image: https://t.co/jWZC4z2rfr

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Our recent scientific confirmation of whale populations in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch underlines the need to clean it up. https://t.co/yinU8z6GOq

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @timwiggins1 @Rapanuiclothing Thanks for the support Tim! Much appreciated.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Our team published a scientific note in the journal Marine Biodiversity reporting on whale sightings in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. These observations show whales are likely impacted by this plastic accumulation zone. Read more in our latest update: https://t.co/jWZC4z2rfr

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Lurker111sw Yes this is us!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @beyondoilsolar @BoyanSlat Thanks for the idea Daniel! We definitely agree our technology should be passive, but instead of melting it into a glob, we will recycle into durable products!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Huskylearner @BoyanSlat Hi Julie, great to see the future generation keen to help. Send us an email via our contact form with all questions, and we can also provide you with some tips: https://t.co/FrD1BZwonr

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @egghead26570992 Thanks for sharing your thoughts! This is one of the challenges we are facing at the moment and are investigating potential solutions. Once we know more, we will update!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @per_earthist @BoyanSlat Thank you so much for donating your miles! We deeply appreciate it as it helps our crew be where they need to in order to solve the challenges ahead.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @ZephyrSpeedShop The fracture occurred at the notches between dovetail connections which causes a high concentration of stress. To better visualize check out our most recent video: https://t.co/hvK3cXYPKh

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: With the root cause analysis complete, results are now being incorporated into design upgrades ahead of system relaunch in the coming months.  https://t.co/hvK3cXYPKh

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Jazzleby Prevention must be coupled with a cleanup. The reality is what we don't clean up will remain in our oceans and continue to breakdown. Following the learnings of this report, we are closer than ever to proof of concept.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: During System 001's 4 months offshore, key features of the cleanup system were confirmed. We also encountered challenges which became the subject of a root cause analysis. We now understand what happened and plan to relaunch in the patch within months: https://t.co/Dag9yT4IYA

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Hoping4Forever Should be out today, stay tuned.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @old_rake Thank you so much for your support! Great to see your support. From our entire team, have the happiest birthday!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @MadeForRain Thanks so much for the support Nikki! We hope you have the best birthday!

text: @whoisheath_ @BoyanSlat Please send an outline of your skills to hr@theoceancleanup.com, and if there is an opportunity to work together, we will be in touch!

text: @rochellemelany Thanks so much for dedicating your birthday fundraiser to us, we appreciate it. Have an amazing birthday!

text: When learning by doing, discovering and resolving issues is an essential part of achieving success. This is the purpose of System 001 and here is the story of its first mission. https://t.co/DTmiZcAYoQ

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Update: good progress is being made on understanding the root causes of Wilson’s issues; we expect to finalize and share the conclusions in coming weeks. With these results, we can begin modifications of the technology and plan for redeployment. https://t.co/PI3VkFniEz

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @UrsusMaritimu53 @BoyanSlat Hello, @UrsusMaritimu53 thank you very much for expressing your concerns, please read our blog post on research about neuston. Here is a link to the blog post:  https://t.co/THzFVhhnUw

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Not exactly “just another day at the office" for our Head of IT who traveled to Hawaii to make sure we fully retrieve over 115 days worth of monitoring and test data from Wilson’s sensors. This data will be playing a key role in the way forward for our system. https://t.co/Xg8XWTUX8j

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: We all want to see clean and safe oceans, which is why we welcome feedback to help us in achieving our mission. A recent piece in @TheAtlantic raised concerns over the neuston. We looked into these claims and share our analysis of the feedback: https://t.co/THzFVhhnUw.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: This is where plastic pollution starts its life. From our latest research published this week. More info: https://t.co/yAVw149iPX https://t.co/LKETJMgpSN

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: RT @PalCommsOA: What can we do to clean up our act? @TheOceanCleanup researchers provide insights into the future of plastic generation & d…
retweet_text: What can we do to clean up our act? @TheOceanCleanup researchers provide insights into the future of plastic generation & disposal: https://t.co/IbyvEI7tmb #environment #plastic #waste #research #TheOceanCleanUp https://t.co/1q5Xzz7jX1

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: In our quest to rid the oceans of plastic, our research team continues to push boundaries in the realm of plastic pollution science. Today, our lead oceanographer published his global assessment of plastic waste generation in @PalCommsOA. Read more: https://t.co/yAVw149iPX

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: This is why we do what we do: approximately 100,000 metric tons of buoyant plastic is currently afloat in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch and it's not going away on its own. Read more from our study results published last March: https://t.co/pWyu5G2OgC https://t.co/UzhCRaz5Ij

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @spoticusmaximus Thank you so much for wanting to support us! You can do so here: https://t.co/rsSiQToqOJ

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: System 001 safely made it back to Hawaii. Now steadily anchored in Hilo Bay where it will receive a complete above and underwater inspection in the next days. This marks the end of the 1st attempt to deploy our full scale cleanup system and the start of our countdown to relaunch. https://t.co/Wc5IHmZYT0

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: UPDATE: System 001 safely made it to Hawaii. It is now 3 nautical miles outside of Hilo Harbor and will be taken in by two local tug boats later today. More tomorrow.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: By tagging along the System 001 deployment mission, our research team was able to perform unprecedented measurements on plastic concentration from surface to seabed. Watch full video on YouTube: https://t.co/l5l4uSjMQ1 https://t.co/OZFllKqTG6

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: At The Ocean Cleanup, we believe that to solve a problem you must fully understand it. Continuing our efforts to understand ocean plastic behavior, we've been conducting offshore research from System 001's monitoring vessel. Learn more: https://t.co/sP7R0XZoFu

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: System 001 has been safely opened and reconnected to the Maersk Transporter. 116 days after launching from San Francisco, the tow back to Hawaii for upgrade and repair has begun. Operations will resume as soon as possible. https://t.co/7H7V6YgvN5

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Following a recent turn of events, we have decided to return System 001 to shore for repair and upgrades. Read more here: https://t.co/LhYST7yH96

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Shift 3 crew arrived at System 001 with a full list of experimental tasks. Partly to try and increase the system's speed through the water, partly to deepen our understanding of the forces that are at work, and turn that knowledge into improvements in a later stage. https://t.co/8qlXYsKBvu

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Shift 3 has arrived at the System 001 location, with a list of tasks to accomplish. Weather permitting, their work will be aimed at improving our understanding of the system’s behavior, and to conduct experiments that may help to increase Wilson’s speed: https://t.co/fBEgQwTy5W

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: After 6 weeks out at sea, our Shift 2 offshore crew completed its monitoring, data collection and research mission. Shift 3 crew just left port, carrying new equipment to further investigate the cleanup system’s behavior and make adjustments. Detailed update coming up next week. https://t.co/VEepOwRDni

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: RT @BoyanSlat: Another ghost net recovered yesterday. Btw, the net we recovered last week weighed 1.5 metric tons (!) https://t.co/OyNJVCle…
retweet_text: Another ghost net recovered yesterday. Btw, the net we recovered last week weighed 1.5 metric tons (!) https://t.co/OyNJVClefp

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Wilson Update: the closing line extension did not effectively increase the span of the system and, therefore, the speed did not improve. Further approaches to widen the u-shape are being evaluated and tested by the team. https://t.co/YP3TFKmnGc

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: While making adjustments to our cleanup system, the crew took the opportunity to recover this large ghostnet drifting by. Note: ghostnets account for 46% of the total mass of plastic in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. https://t.co/ZTHEiVD5RE

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @egghead26570992 Thanks for your support ! The webcam is OK but there is a website bug on the System 001 page. We are working on a fix.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: After collecting and analyzing field data, initial observations show that the system collects plastic but that it also drifts out. Modifications are now being prepared to tune the system. Read more in our latest update. https://t.co/n4jKKrU2mK

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Live location, environmental data and system camera feed are now available 24/7 on our website. Track System 001: https://t.co/1BtgT8VOAz https://t.co/QySPp1tGVk

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: The 2nd shift crew is approaching System 001 in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch after a brief transition period between vessels. While the 1st shift focused on installation, evaluating performance and troubleshooting now take priority. 1st results and observations coming soon. https://t.co/gmsqDYac9b

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Maersk Launcher left Wilson, soon to be relieved by Maersk Transporter to continue monitoring and plastic collection in the coming months. We'd like to thank the 30-person crew on board and @Maersk, @MaerskSupply and @DeepGreenMetals for making this first shift successful. https://t.co/ccCEZvq7QV

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: RT @BoyanSlat: First plastic https://t.co/53nSlLSytf

text: @daniello_ello @dieter4nature @BoyanSlat You can find it here: https://t.co/VESdnUcYb0

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Watch a recap of System 001’s trials and deployment. Project Manager Henk van Dalen explains the recent progress and steps forward. https://t.co/NYq1b1QVib

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: This week, we deployed System 001 in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. In the upcoming months, we are hoping to confirm its plastic capturing efficiency and survivability; thus proving our technology. Read more in our latest update. https://t.co/c7D3x6Db3k

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Gerald_van_Dijk See also our explainer video of how the system works here: https://t.co/6i6Bi6LRQo

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @Gerald_van_Dijk We changed from the 100km long V-shaped moored barrier, to a free floating fleet of systems. Since the fleet will be free floating, it will be drifting to where the plastic is concentrating, making the cleanup faster. See the announcement from May 2017: https://t.co/RdYMFH6I3A

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Installation successfully completed. Thank you to the offshore crew for your work. We are ready to start the cleanup. https://t.co/kiX39Aw1aw

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @stok_01 The patch is an accumulation zone, where plastic gets 'trapped' by converging currents. It contains ~80K tonnes of plastic, dispersed over an are 2x Texas. Hence, we developed a passive method to concentrate it first, before taking it out.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Happening now: We have arrived at the deployment location in the heart of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, and the crew is putting the system into its designated U-shape. The operation is going smoothly. More updates to come. https://t.co/pHVFu1fgam

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @PeteBlacker @CarmenC97414191 @IridiumBoss Iridium is a partner of ours.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @CarmenC97414191 We have an onboard reporter who is recording video and taking pictures. However, the internet connection in the Pacific is not the best for video transfer. We will share videos as soon as possible.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @schumie71 We will have a feed of images (roughly an image an hour) taken by the system on our website shortly.  https://t.co/1BtgT8VOAz

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: We are almost at the deployment location in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch at 143.83°W, 30.89°N. Roughly 50 nautical miles to go. https://t.co/NxFtuDLvEv

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: The Go/No-Go meeting held earlier this week was the last chance for the team to bring concerns and issues to the table. After two hours of evaluation and discussion, it was concluded that System 001 shall continue to the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. https://t.co/49xlNjcP3a

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: 14 days since the Pacific Trials began; while the test plan is a little behind schedule, the engineering team has not yet seen any unexpected issues and aims to conduct the final tests this weekend. https://t.co/Ms8mij9UGq

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: The team performs aerial inspections twice a day. During these, they record behavioral data of the system and inspect its integrity. A thermal camera will also be used to monitor sea life in the vicinity of the system. And every once in a while, they snap a stunning sunset image. https://t.co/ntNVMDossv

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Today, we published our results on the analysis of hyper-spectral imagery collected during our 2016 Aerial Expedition above the Great Pacific Garbage Patch in Environmental Science & Technology https://t.co/HfWehXpcAd

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Pacific Trials update: unfavorable weather over the last couple days prevented the offshore crew from running new tests. Priority was given to daily system inspections as well as deploying our autonomous environmental monitoring drone ship @AutoNautUSV. To be continued. https://t.co/HXSM34NK18

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Timelapse drone shot of System 001 during one of the re-orientation tests. If it performs well for the remaining tests, we will have another checklist item completed. https://t.co/u630jEX2KZ

text: Clear blue skies and calm waters, perfect conditions to perform the first installation of System 001 at the test site. The Pacific Trial phase has begun. https://t.co/MmOFtoowqu

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: As we're approaching the test site, the crew is preparing the closing lines to lock the system in operational configuration. At this point, the wind and waves will have helped the system form its U-shape. https://t.co/4PKtZl6bhQ

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: After 5 days in transit, System 001 will arrive at the Pacific test site tonight (PT). The trials, which will hopefully confirm the basic concept of the cleanup system, will begin tomorrow. https://t.co/kxUNjRFfJ4

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @BannedButNotFor The system has been engineered and tested to utilize and withstand the forces of the ocean. While designing the structure, we considered load cases that are only expected to occur once every hundred years.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @vmatzeetc There are several steps you can take to prevent plastic pollution, but some depend on recycling facilities in your area. Organize beach cleanups, reduce your use of disposable plastics, reuse & recycle, or make a donation: https://t.co/WpsfHL6w73. Thanks for your support!

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @RonaBerg Our plan is to recycle the plastic and turn it into feedstock for durable products. We hope to be able to fund the expansion of our cleanup, from the Great Pacific Garbage Patch to the other four gyres, with the help of this revenue.

text: @rcrobjohn @Benioff @nadhimzahawi @BoyanSlat This plastic will be brought back to shore. High-quality material will be mechanically recycled to serve as feedstock for new products. Lower-quality material will be converted into energy, by thermal recycling.

Corporations that have shown their interest in participating in the cleanup, have been given the opportunity to sponsor their own cleanup system or an entire fleet.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: In exactly two weeks, we will launch our first cleanup system from San Francisco, into the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. We would like you to join us for this milestone, either in person or online. For schedule, viewing spots and the livestream, visit: https://t.co/1BtgT8VOAz

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: [16 days to launch] The final weld of System 001 (aka Wilson) is in the box. https://t.co/O3vrvzIjhx

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Note that on this aerial shot, we can clearly see how the floater absorbs the energy of the wind waves, which is the main driving force behind the cleanup system.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: [21 days to launch] We are currently assembling the stabilizers of the cleanup system, which provide stability to the system and prevent it from rotating. In total, ten of these stabilizers will be attached to the system, consisting of either single or double floaters. https://t.co/tPG1dXhdsR

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: At The Ocean Cleanup we welcome all thoughtful critique and value the insight, but recently we experienced something different. https://t.co/HSuCcvHQt3

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: [23 days to launch] These empty containers just arrived at the yard. They will be loaded on our deployment and support vessel, the @Maersk Launcher. If all goes according to plan, they will soon come back filled with the first plastic collected by System 001. https://t.co/a7yWaMxzlt

You can now support The Ocean Cleanup by donating Flying Blue Miles

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: [28 days to launch] The system 001 assembly just passed the halfway mark. A few numbers to put this in perspective: 353.03 meters of floater have been welded, 204 meters of skirt is now attached below it, 1632 bolts have been tightened to connect the two. https://t.co/lYZS3GKKaw

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: [31 days to launch] Meanwhile in Rotterdam, the research team is gearing up for a thorough data collection expedition, which will be running during the System 001 deployment. https://t.co/ye0mDazzxp

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: As the world’s first ocean cleanup system is taking shape in California, the crew has started the painting. This includes both functional markings, as well as logos and the soon-to-be-revealed name of the system. https://t.co/5mEeTL5AUp

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @FreeThinkerG 120m-long section of the world's first ocean cleanup system, being tested for seaworthiness

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: We asked one of our crew members to provide us with a recap of the tow test, just as he stepped back on land after two weeks at sea. Read more about the results in our latest update: https://t.co/Ru7HSiHgYt https://t.co/7dlJqcD41x

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: The recently completed tow test was a crucial milestone on the road to the deployment of the world’s first ocean cleanup system. Here is an update on how it went. https://t.co/Ru7HSiHgYt

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: First footage from our successful tow test. We will share detailed results next week. https://t.co/qp8JXWQpsx

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Today is the 1st day we spend in our new headquarters in Rotterdam. A few kilometers from Delft where it all began five years ago, this new office offers much more space and a great work environment. We’d like to thank Stichting De Verre Bergen for donating this new space to us. https://t.co/E2yY7NiIPO

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: RT @BoyanSlat: The Ocean Cleanup assembly yard from above. The black sub-assemblies are each 8% of the total length of the cleanup system.…
retweet_text: The Ocean Cleanup assembly yard from above. The black sub-assemblies are each 8% of the total length of the cleanup system. The white box is the welding station. https://t.co/eJFDe5Juwi

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Back on solid ground: with the tow test successfully completed, the yard crew received the green light to continue the assembly. The test piece has now been cut in half, allowing us to put the remaining sections in between in the coming weeks. https://t.co/SBuD6QKZF8

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @MartinRoc_ We sure did ;) https://t.co/yXWTH5kMS0

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: This clip we received from the assembly yard could make you think the crew lost their mind. But the reason they just cut the 120-meter tow test unit in half is to move ahead with the assembly and insert the remaining 480 meters to complete the full 600-meter system. #gopro https://t.co/FbviACwC9e

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: RT @Benioff: Congrats @BoyanSlat @TheOceanCleanup I cant believe how far your vision has come into reality from meeting you on Twitter four…
retweet_text: Congrats @BoyanSlat @TheOceanCleanup I cant believe how far your vision has come into reality from meeting you on Twitter four years ago.  Everything you said would happen is happening! Next step: 90% reduction in plastic in the ocean.  https://t.co/ZDbpdg0Etu

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Today, we entered into a unique agreement with the Netherlands relating to the deployment of our cleanup systems on the high seas. This agreement confirms that the Netherlands seeks to actively support and facilitate The Ocean Cleanup’s activities: https://t.co/JcvvZDKczx https://t.co/mxYTmp7l8a

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @harryr33 Good question! We also think that stopping the influx is definitely a must. However, our focus right now is the gyres, in which 92 % of the mass is still to be found in the larger objects. We need to stop them from breaking down into microplastics before it is too late.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @danandhisbass Thank you for your curiosity! You can follow our progress here: https://t.co/MZ7wECT0KZ. It is funded by individuals and corporations. We plan on having a fleet of 60 systems in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, and then expand to the other 4 gyres.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @danandhisbass @sandronunes93 @ChefJuliaKeene @GlblCtzn @RachelMiner1 Our cleanup system does not have a net, we have an impermeable screen underneath the floater, which will concentrate the sub-surface plastic.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @ccsurvivor45 @GlblCtzn @LeoDiCaprio Thanks for your interest in helping us out! Please contact us through our contact form: https://t.co/xEp2V1xRBa

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @melissasantucci @GlblCtzn Our cleanup system does not have nets. It is designed to concentrate plastic, meanwhile sealife can pass underneath or around it. https://t.co/xYP4AG6cCY

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @irishiiiz97739 @GlblCtzn @RachelMiner1 Our cleanup system is designed to concentrate plastic, not to trap anything. You can see more about the design here: https://t.co/xYP4AG6cCY

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Just in: the offshore crew made it back into the San Francisco Bay after more than two weeks testing the 120-meter unit in towing configuration. Test results will be shared as we process them. More explanation about the tow test: https://t.co/AbX58EeHUX https://t.co/bIfW7qjT7j

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @rejectedbanana @BoyanSlat You're in luck! CSA Ocean Sciences will complete their study in a few weeks from now.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Five years ago, cleaning the oceans was an idea deemed impossible. This year, we will launch the world's first operational ocean cleanup system. https://t.co/ddaKnwk3sd

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @JenRacc The number one reason we’re developing ocean cleanup technology is to stop the destruction plastic is causing to hundreds of species worldwide. Making sure our systems do not negatively impact (marine) life is our number one design driver. More: https://t.co/3YOsPY3k6S

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Tow test update: the team is taking advantage of a calm weather window to inspect the 120-meter test section. They just reported that the system came out of last week's rough testing conditions without significant issues. https://t.co/jj1VkMeRZW

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Five days into our tow test, here is an overview of the steps we’re taking to launch the world’s first operational ocean cleanup system in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. https://t.co/w8xzx9YakB

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Checking progress on the assembly of the first cleanup system’s electronic components. Sticking with our principle of working with nature, the system will rely on the sun to power everything from AIS, satellite communications, cameras and sensors. https://t.co/obtusDhkoy

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: RT @BoyanSlat: Giving a speech at the Internation Maritime Organisation’s safety committee today. Safety for all life at sea is our number…
retweet_text: Giving a speech at the Internation Maritime Organisation’s safety committee today. Safety for all life at sea is our number 1 priority. https://t.co/aap869gPnE

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: The 120-meter unit is now offshore in tow configuration. Read more about the tow test: https://t.co/AbX58EeHUX https://t.co/t9lP2ejzup

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Our tow test has left Alameda and is on its way to the Pacific Ocean. https://t.co/K3I4h129hP

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Happening now: the tow test departure has just been confirmed. The 120-meter sub system unit should be leaving Alameda within the next few hours. Stay tuned for more updates over the weekend.

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: The 120-meter tow test unit is now completely lowered into the lagoon, where it will receive full inspection and final checks before departure. https://t.co/POl0mExw3e

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Just before we put the 120-meter section into the water for the tow test, here’s a recap of the work accomplished on the assembly yard for the first cleanup system https://t.co/h71y0sUzKF

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: As the tow test of the 120-meter unit approaches, @boyanslat summarizes what is left to accomplish before we launch the first cleanup system into the Great Pacific Garbage Patch later this summer. https://t.co/0tkmAubXKj

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Testing is key to our iterative design process, and with the latest series of scale model tests performed at @MARIN_nieuws we have further validated design elements of System 001 https://t.co/lMZGZUx039

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Having completed all welds for the 120-meter test section, the assembly crew has now moved into the screen assembly phase. The tow-test is scheduled to occur within the next two weeks, weather permitting. Follow the road to the cleanup: https://t.co/MZ7wECT0KZ https://t.co/GYXsORGPh3

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: RT @Benioff: The ocean clean up is now building their first systems for deployment in Emeryville.  The idea is simple to clean up the garba…

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @KPIXtv Thanks for joining us today!

text: RT @simongerman600: Seeing the Great Pacific Garbage Patch on a #map made me realize how insanely big it is (1.6 million sqkm which is larg…
retweet_text: Seeing the Great Pacific Garbage Patch on a #map made me realize how insanely big it is (1.6 million sqkm which is larger than #Mongolia or #Iran). Look how it dwarfs #Hawaii. As humans we have to manage our consumption in a more sustainable way. Source: https://t.co/KwtDev5AKm https://t.co/WpehLX67qt

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: The crew has successfully completed the first weld of two floater sections, officially marking the beginning of the assembly. In total, 51 of these sections will be put together. At the 120-meter mark, we will take the system out for a tow-test https://t.co/MZ7wECT0KZ https://t.co/HuXVGN4C1M

name: The Ocean Cleanup

retweet_text: New research from @theoceancleanup: Great Pacific Garbage Patch four to 16 times bigger than previously thought, comprising an estimated 1.8 trillion pieces of rubbish. #CleanSeas  https://t.co/RtXiLxBbt7

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: RT @BoyanSlat: What products should we make out of the plastic we'll be collecting from the Great Pacific Garbage Patch? https://t.co/8OxGs…
retweet_text: What products should we make out of the plastic we'll be collecting from the Great Pacific Garbage Patch? https://t.co/8OxGsT6bKa

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: Common question we received after last week's publication: 'can we see pictures of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch?'Although the total mass of plastic is large, it is spread out over a large area. These pictures show typical densities encountered for micro, macro and mega debris. https://t.co/h0YniQhtEY

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @TheFeenie1 @BoyanSlat Hello. The email address is active and should work. Please send an email via our contact form: https://t.co/FrD1BZwonr

name: The Ocean Cleanup
text: @elena_ferrel @ABC Since the area is so large, actively going after the very dispersped plastic is not a feasible solution. This is why we are developing a passive cleanup system, that will move with the waves, just like the plastic, to concentrate it. https://t.co/xYP4AFOBeo

name: The Ocean Cleanup
